ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course provides an excellent survey of 19th- and 20th century French and German poetry, in verse and prose.
You learn the backgrounds and poetry of prominent French poets.
I got an in-depth look at the studied poets (their biographies and their work), and became a much better essay writer.
This class showed me a new way of reading poetry, just letting the verses flow, without trying to capture and understand every single word. It also opened me to reading more foreign poetry.
I learned the life story and about the poems of a series of French and German poets who were insane, eccentric, or both. I also improved my essay writing and analysis skills significantly.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Connolley is an incredible lecturer and provided a lot of insight on the different poets we discussed.  We discussed a poet a week, which was ample time to know the background of the poet, but I feel like we didn't delve too deeply on the poetry itself.  It is a great overview class to touch on the different "mad poets" and the exploration of the relation between madness and poetry was incredibly interesting.
The lectures were always interesting and engaging. I especially loved the essay assignmentsthey were valuable opportunities to go more in-depth with particular poets.

Strengths: the lectures were great and very well-structured. The way the assignments are designed leaves a lot of freedom for students, which I really liked. Sections allowed to dive deeper into the study of a specific poem and allows to vocalize thoughts that weren't mentioned in lecture (even though the format of lectures are made somewhat interactive by Prof Connolly). Weaknesses: I don't see any big weakness, apart maybe from the lecture hall the lecture was given in. Maybe one with a blackboard would be beneficial. I also wished that Prof Connolly would not read his lecture notes sometimes, and allow himself to maybe diverge from the initial plan.
Classes and sections were engaging. I got a lot of feedback on my essay, which really improved my essay writing skills throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course was interesting and not overly demanding.
I would recommend the course to any student who is interested in poetry and the literature of the 19th and 20th centuries.

Yes! The content is quite interesting and the Professor and TAs are wonderful for feedback and learning. If you are interested in poetry or looking for a relatively easy writing credit, this is a great class.

I would recommend this course to anyone, even if they had no intention of studying poetry further. I think it's a wonderful glimpse into poetic potential, and is also great for learning to write better essays.
Absolutely! It is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale.
I would recommend this course to another student interested in the topic. You will learn a lot and will also have a chance to improve your writing skills.
